page.title: 07BARNS AT BALDON HOUSE
page.content: Dating from early C18,but incorporating a C17 dividing wall,is a Z-shaped group of tile-roofed farm buildings which now form a mellow garden backdrop;cover for summer parties and storage space. A 90ft gable-ended roof spans two brick and stone cowhouses or stables, with loft above,which adjoin a 5 bay threshing barn,24ft high,with 3ft stone and brick wall supporting the timber frame. Cruck blades rise to collars from the tie beams. Elm is the main timber. The barn is fully clad with the exception of the central bay where the doors used to hang. The south slope of the tiled roof is extended on each side of the doorway,forming an aisle, originally constructed as a cattle shelter. Adjoining,and of similar construction are two further barns, running North/ South then East/West.
